parent_msg:
<!subteam^S0276B95C2G> on prod VM we are able to see CPU utilisation at 70-75% in Observablity window for this instance `mcache-cntr-shared-edge-proxy-secondary-1-prd-ase1` in central-prd project. But while doing htop in the instance its just 38% utilised! Can we check this and if this is an issue then can we raise a ticket with GCP?
cc: <@U026D2W91KN>

replies.msg: <@U03CK6N6YG6>, The actual CPU utilization is around 30–35%, but the system is I/O-bound, with 67–68% of CPU time spent in I/O wait, which is the major bottleneck.

GCP's cpu utilisation considers only user + system time (excludes i/o wait) -- basically doing actual work.

so by this calculation gcp console's cpu utilisation seems off to us.

Based on the documentation the metrics that GCP Console provides are of the hypervisord instance (cpu usage of instance + hypervisor overhead) we can enable ops-agent that will give us the same utilization as by the `top, htop or node-exporter` 
So the metric we are looking at doesn't include what is actually happening at the physical host. Usually that overhead is very low as in the other case but we should look deeper as it might affect performance in the longer term.

replies.msg:
Hi <@U06FV97K2F2>,
It’s already 7 PM, and I won’t be able to take up this release until Monday.

I noticed that the PR has been closed, reopened, and converted to draft multiple times. Could we take a moment to look into the root cause of these issues? Ideally, the PR should pass in the first attempt, so understanding what’s going wrong will help us avoid these repeated cycles.

Additionally, I observed that every time the PR is marked as “draft” and then moved back to “ready for review,” it retriggers the entire deployment on pre-prod along with all GitHub checks. Would it be possible to implement a check at the commit level to avoid unnecessary re-deployments in such scenarios?

<@U05M2GBQAL8>
As discussed we are observing [HystrixEventShortCircuited] error in huge number under the nodes where response time is high , there was one more occurrence at ~7:03 PM . Multiple nodes at that time had high response time.
Also pods under these nodes were getting  probe failures for readiness and liveliness.
"Probe failed" probeType="Readiness"

<@U05M2GBQAL8> while you investigate on the issues, it doesnt seem specifically node issue but the long runnign noicy neighbour issue. And I see since this is one of the most used service can we invest some time to tune on the below paramaters as well:
1. We are running ~380 pods, can we vertically scale this to see if this scaling helps in these startup issues. (in general we scale in bunch of 30 pods at peak)
2. Can we also try tuning the slow start with the stricter HPA thresholds so that this scaling can be less drastic.
cc: <@U03MYJKGPDE> <@U039QSD6SGN> <@U02GB3Q9CQK>

just to add to <@U039GPMUX8X> point
As we discussed these issues happened during deployments ( both the occurrences ~3:46 PM and 7:03 PM) and issue was mainly in newly created nodes( some times even with out deployment new nodes are having high response times initially )
Can we reduce the slowStartaggression  to 0.3 so that ramp up of traffic is smooth

```(sum by (uri,httpCode) (CONTROLLER_execTime_count{service="supplier-platform-promotions",httpCode=~"4[0-9]{2}", uri!~".*health.*|.*actuator.*", env="prod"}) / 60) * 60 >= 70```

replies.msg:
<@U05T50S9REF> the usage of telegraf metrics and its validation should be performed on your end, plz have a conversation with your team on how you want to test,use the alerts.

In pulse every dev has permission to try/test/validate out alerts. Other than the existing 4xx you can have another one as well but we don't allow on changing the 4xx envoy queried alert.

So yeah you can go ahead and test out the req. things in pulse itself.
If i can't change the existing alert then what's the point of having a new alert with higher threshold?
thats what, all 4xx and 5xx envoy alerts are in standardised manner, currently we don't support for changing those.

<@U05T50S9REF>
we can create these alerts as per our requirement , we can also change the existing 4XX alert as well. But we do recommend to use envoy metric in which we do not have option to exclude api.

But still if we want to update the alert we can go ahead and change the query as per our wish.

you can also create separate alert for that specific api with higher threshold as well.
If you still have further queries please let me know we can connect over a huddle and resolve this

thanks <@U039QSD6SGN>

waiting for the next 4xx alert, if we get both alerts,

1. We are getting 503's (are we priting the logs for these req anywhere) , 503's usually occur due to issue at server side, (may be their server is having maintenance or a temporary load etc.)

what exactly is gatekeeper doing (it's just a proxy to outgoing requests) right?

<@U03L5EF8TV4> makes sense,

504 (Gateway Timeout) would be if the request-response had timed out. Since connection itself couldn’t get established, such cases are classified as 503s (Service Unavailable)

thanks <@U07BQR9SBLM> <@U07B72HU81W> for help in analysing issue over here. we have collated few solid points on the reasons of downtime, and i am working further on its analysis.
CC: <@U02HAH0C8AE> <@U041Z2SFBQS>
<@U03BDUPU7P1> can you please share those point here?
<@U02GB3Q9CQK> i am also working on few open points on my end over this issue, planning to udpate the details of our discussion and analysis either by tonight, or by monday
<@U03BDUPU7P1> Any update on this?

RCA Summary (In Progress)
During both outages, we observed that individual pods were reaching 100% CPU usage at the very beginning of the incident. Correlating with the logs from `kube-events` in Elastic, we confirmed that the pods with high CPU usage were also experiencing liveness probe failures during that time. Below are a few SS samples from the incident window.
We identified a cascading failure pattern:
• As certain pods hit 100% CPU, their liveness probes started failing.
• This led Kubernetes to route traffic to the remaining healthy pods.
• The increased load on these pods caused them to also reach high CPU, triggering their own liveness probe failures.
• This repeated across pods, leading to a cascading failure.
A day before the incident, we had updated the autoscaling policy to trigger at 65% CPU utilization. During the daytime load test, no issues were observed. However, it’s possible that, despite increased traffic, the pods were not scaling up effectively.
Upon further investigation, we found that:
• There were intermittent CPU spikes at the pod level, where usage jumped from 50% to 100% within seconds.
• This spiky behavior was present earlier too, but after increasing the CPU utilization threshold to 65%, these spikes started consistently hitting 100%.
• Because of the spiky nature of CPU usage, the HPA (Horizontal Pod Autoscaler) did not get a stable 2-minute window to trigger scale-out. This led to insufficient scaling during critical times.
Current RCA Points and Action Items
• We noticed that this issue is more prevalent in *Go-based services*, where CPU usage fluctuates by ±20%.
• In contrast, *Java-based services* show relatively stable CPU usage, with fluctuations of around ±10%.
• Due to this high fluctuation in Go services, autoscaling becomes unreliable unless:
    ◦ A scheduled scaling policy is in place (as is currently done in the MP cluster), or
    ◦ There is a sufficient buffer in CPU limits to prevent spikes from reaching 90%+ usage.
We are currently investigating the cause of this spiky behavior in the *ranking Go services*, and are also comparing this with other Golang-based services used at Meesho.
To complete this RCA, we aim to understand the CPU usage pattern end-to-end and determine whether this is a Go runtime characteristic, a code-level inefficiency, or a scaling misconfiguration.
CC: <@U041Z2SFBQS> <@U02GB3Q9CQK> <@U020M7DSKV1>

> Graceful shutdown support was added in Spring Boot 2.3 (release in May, 2020). This allows active requests to complete before closing the context, and shutting down container.

> • stop accepting new requests
> • will wait for some _configurable_ time to process already accepted requests
> • stop container
> • stop embedded server

replies.msg: <!subteam^S0276B95C2G> anyone available ?
checkin
++ <@U041Z2SFBQS> <@U020M7DSKV1>
As a result this is impacting entire MP clusters
Is this resolved <@U06MFAMKYDP> <@U02E6BXGM0B>?
have increased it through argocd the min and max values ++ <@U021DF7L7CY>

<@U02E6BXGM0B> just a quick update on the issue we saw with the min/max count being incorrectly set to 2/5 via Ringmaster’s autoscaling properties update feature.

Although Ringmaster correctly updated the values in the values.yaml file (min: 210, max: 600), Ringmaster still applied the canary values (2:5). This happened because Ringmaster doesn’t perform a full ArgoCD app sync when using this update feature, it only updates the ScaledObject (HPA).

ArgoCD determines which scaling properties to apply based on the presence of the canary object. Since we had recently enabled canary (via values.yaml) but hadn’t synced the Argo app after enabling canary, the canary object (prd-gpmc-service) was technically present but in a MISSING state.

Ringmaster detected the presence of the canary object (in MISSING state) and used its min/max scaling values, and applying them to the main scaledObject (since canary was not present yet). Since the primary ScaledObject wasn’t present (also due to the lack of a sync), Ringmaster likely attempted to update it as well and failed though this error wasn’t handled, which led to the above issue.

++ <@U06MFAMKYDP>
<@U021DF7L7CY> please manually reduce the min count for *gpmc-service*
to what count?
updated.

model-proxy-service-fy-ad. I have manually increased the min count for now
<@U06MFAMKYDP> this is EKS infra dashboard : <https://grafana-prd.meeshogcp.in/goto/sT0w8sfHR?orgId=1>
<@U02E6BXGM0B> please put down a meet link. <@U06MFAMKYDP>, <@UBCAB5YES> can you guys please join
<https://meet.google.com/bqb-yowi-hke>

HPA uses a *tolerance window* (±10% by default). For a 70% target, the upper threshold becomes *77%*.
When CPU was between *70%*- *76%*, it remained *within the tolerance* range (<*77%*), so *no further scaling* was triggered here.
++ <@U06FV97K2F2>
we can reduce the trigger to lesser value than 70 to make it scale at 70

<@U06MFAMKYDP> <@UBCAB5YES> I feel 10% is a bit much, shall me change it to 5%
```behavior:
  scaleUp:
    tolerance: 0.05```
?
Yeah we will reduce the threshold for time being, but having a 10% tolerance makes the scaling a bit unpredictable
Configurable tolerance feature's `alpha` version just got released last month (as part of the latest k8s release - 1.33). Since it is in very early stages, we might not be able to use it currently
we can have the trigger at 64 -> scaling will happen at >70.4, or at 63 -> scaling will happen at >69.3
<@U03BDUPU7P1> ++

parent_msg:
<!subteam^S0276B95C2G> avg latency of our API in MPPL is `20ms`. This API is consumed by cart service in FTPL. In cart service the avg latency is over `300ms`
Can you please help reduce this network latency

replies.msg:
MPPL service : user-lending
FTPL service : cart

Due to hight latency we have multiple timeouts on cart

<@U0812HT8S2J>
Please correct if I am wrong, this call is being over public network, as there is no peering between mppl and ftpl
300ms is due to the call being made via public network and going via Akamai for WAF

Can we add peering to reduce this?

Right now cart directly makes API call to the public host of user-lending

No, as these are separate entities, the decision was made to keep the infra separate as well.
cc: <@U03DM679GAH>
<@U03BGN9H5R8> is there any way to reduce this latency?
any alternate route?

The difference right now is huge.
avg on MPPL is `20s` on FTPL it is over `300ms` . Timeout on cart is `350ms` .
Due to this we have ~30% timeouts

We can add a feature on akamai, that helps identify the fastest route to origin from akamai edge locations. But the best it will help with is 10-20ms, it will require few changes on the service at mppl end, there is not much we can do for public api calls.
I will also check with akamai support if there are any other optimisations possible.

But I think we should increase the timeout on cart end for public calls.

Increasing timeout on cart won't be possible.

Can we check with Akamai and see if there are any alternatives? If not we can evaluate the change that you are suggesting

<@U03BGN9H5R8> is it possible to have VPC peering on specific API routes?
if that is possible we can justify by providing some proof on these whitelists, also it will solve the latency issue.

No <@U03DM679GAH>
Thats not possible, without using additional services by Google like cloud armour, which has a significant cost associated with it
In that case can we please check with Akamai once <@U03BGN9H5R8>?
have a call scheduled for tomorrow with Akamai

<@U03DM679GAH> <@U0812HT8S2J>
A ticket is open with Akamai and their team will be coming back their findings.
Meanwhile we are also evaluating a setup wherein we will have a proxy setup in a separate project in mppl with vpc peering with both mppl and ftpl, which will only allow only certain api's to be accessible by ftpl.
cc: <@U08P934LX6W> <@U039GPMUX8X>
